title: Jose Mourinho's call for the media to "tell the truth" is just camouflaging more Manchester United mediocrity
text:
Sport Opinion Jose Mourinho's call for the media to "tell the truth" is just camouflaging more Manchester United mediocrity If he is treated differently to other misbehaving managers it is because he has serious form, Europe-wide — repeat offenders get bigger raps than first offenders Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Jose Mourinho rants after Hull draw Share this video Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
It started as a boast, now it has become a whinge. 
Manchester United manager Mourinho claims he is treated differently from the rest, his misdemeanours punished more harshly than those of his Arsenal and Liverpool counterparts Arsene Wenger and Jurgen Klopp. 
It is, pretty much, nonsense. 
The FA’s disciplinary system, and football officialdom in general, might be flawed but it is flawed for everyone. 
In a clear reference to Wenger’s recent punishment , Mourinho pointed out that he had to watch a game from a hotel last season. 
The reason he had to watch a game from a hotel is that he refused to leave the referee’s changing-room at half-time during a match at Upton Park, and was so aggressive and abusive he had to be escorted out by the stadium’s head of security. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Jose Mourinho takes a very obvious dig at Jürgen Klopp Share this video Watch Next 
Wenger’s punishment WAS lenient, I agree ; but his offence was a petulant one. Mourinho’s at West Ham that day was a more sinister one. 
If Mourinho is treated differently it is because he has serious form, Europe-wide. 
That’s what happens, it’s called the law. Repeat offenders get bigger raps than first offenders. 
Mourinho had a valid point about Klopp, but there is no doubt the German’s apologetic nature and his subsequent decent humour helps his cause. 
Are officials likely to be more forgiving to someone who seems genuinely contrite than to someone who has become overwhelmingly sarcastic, snarly and sardonic? 
That’s what happens, it’s called human nature. 
Where Mourinho doesn’t have a point is in his inference that there is some sort of refereeing conspiracy against him and his team ON the field. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now 'Angry' Jose Mourinho walks out of TV interview Share this video Watch Next 
Referring to the reporters in the room, Mourinho said: “You simply have to just tell the truth and if you go game after game with Manchester United and you see what happened here with Manchester City, what happened here with Burnley… what happened almost everywhere… 
"You do your job and you do a public service, I think. 
“Tell the truth.” 
Well, the truth is United should have had a penalty in that Manchester derby for Claudio Bravo’s challenge on Wayne Rooney and that Matteo Darmian was probably fouled inside the area against Burnley. 
The truth is also that Marcos Rojo somehow avoided a red card for one of the season’s more heinous fouls against Everton, while United’s equaliser against Liverpool originated from a cross by a player in an offside position . 
That’s the truth. Yes, United should have been awarded a penalty for this... ...like Rojo ought to have seen red and not yellow here (Photo: Sky Sports/Ruckas) 
The truth is, everybody gets good and bad decisions in equal measure. 
There was no conspiracy against Mourinho’s Chelsea of last season, as he claimed, and no conspiracy against his Man United of this season, as he seems to be claiming. 
There is erroneous officiating, but only because the pace of Premier league play is so unrelenting and demanding for referees, while cheating players have become experts at conning them. 
It is a cocktail certain to produce mistakes. Even Mourinho must, deep down, know this. 
But his snappiness on Wednesday night was designed to do just one thing —camouflage another mediocre result in what has been a mediocre first Premier League season for him at Old Trafford. Mourinho's rants are a smokescreen to hide his underwhelming debut season at United (Photo: Reuters) 
In the top flight, Mourinho has drawn or lost more matches than he has won. That is mediocre for a Man United manager. 
He has just two points more than David Moyes had at this stage in his one and only season at United and one less than Louis van Gaal had after 23 games in the first of his two seasons. 
And that after being afforded the luxury of spending over £150million on players in the summer. 
His rant about Klopp and Wenger is a smokescreen intended to hide the fact that for all the array of attacking talent at his disposal, Mourinho is embarrassingly reliant on a 35-year-old Zlatan Ibrahmovic for goals. After 30-something Zlatan, United's next highest scorer has just FOUR goals (Photo: Reuters) 
The Swede has 14. 
Next on the list are Juan Mata and Paul Pogba, with four each. 
That is the sort of issue Mourinho should be addressing, not whingeing about who gets what punishment. 
Mourinho claims to be treated as ‘different’. 
He needs to get back to doing what he did to make him different in the first place. Like us on Facebook
